ab9a5eb8-0ee0-4778-825d-649aa3ae47e5.description: The FWM, or Forestry Works Manager, is the person or organisation who commissions the work on a forestry site. This one day course is designed for Forestry Works Managers, Site Supervisors, Team Leaders and those managing forestry operations. This course will provide a general oversight and awareness of the responsibilities of a Forestry Works Manager. This course is also suitable as a Refresher for those who have previously undertaken FISA FWM Training.
ab9a5eb8-0ee0-4778-825d-649aa3ae47e5.name: Forestry Works Manager Awareness Training

badge_template_activities.title: Overview of the UK Legal System
Understanding Responsibilities with regards to UK Health and Safety Law
FISA guidance on Managing Health and Safety in Forestry
Effective Planning and Risk Assessment - managing and mitigating risks
Contractor Management and Engagement
Site Management and Considerations
Operational Hazards and Controls
Incident Management and Investigation
Implementing a Safety First Culture into the workplace

skills.name: Health And Safety At Work Act

a7a1958c-15dc-4787-9747-a801785bfe76.description: Earners of this badge have attended a mwmac Standard Setting event, run annually by mwmac Ltd.
a7a1958c-15dc-4787-9747-a801785bfe76.name: mwmac Ltd Standard Setting 2022

badge_template_activities.title: This attendee has been present, in person or via zoom, at this years mwmac Ltd Standard Setting event.
This attendee was provided with Welsh Funding Updates, for projects such as Farming Connect, Focus on Forestry First and Tyfu Cymru. As well as updates on mwmac now being an ELCAS approved provider.
This attendee was provided with updates on Future Developments within Land-based Services at City & Guilds NPTC by Chris Jones (Industry Manager for Landbased Services - C&G NPTC).
This attendee was provided with an introduction to The DPJ Foundation by Nikki Jones. The DPJ Foundation is a mental health charity for the Agricultural Industries.

This attendee was provided with administrative updates on the mwmac Ltd processes for both training and assessment events. This covered items such as paperwork, confirmation emails, welfare, house-keeping and general professional conduct.

This attendee was provided with administrative updates on the mwmac Ltd Out Centre Service for individuals and businesses that register their Lantra Awards or City & Guilds NPTC Candidates through mwmac Ltd. This covered items such as admin processes, paperwork, awarding body updates, assessor specific information and general conduct and professionalism.

This attendee was provided with an in-depth explanation on the Digital Credentials System through Credly and City & Guilds. This included information on how to access their own Digital Credentials, how to share the Digital Credentials and use them to their advantage. This attendee was also provided information on how mwmac Ltd will now also be utilising the Credly platform for their own Certification purposes.
This attendee was provided with information on future updates within mwmac Ltd and the direction within which the internal processes may head in the future.
This attendee was provided with an opportunity to network with other instructors and assessors.

a9fa218d-d184-464a-a777-d86356c53f00.description: This course is for new and non-qualified chainsaw operators. This is a hands-on course that delivers both practical skills and health and safety guidance as well as demonstrating that you and your employer have completed sufficient training to meet the Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998 (PUWER). This course is for those who are likely to be cutting timber that is already on the ground, but not felling.
a9fa218d-d184-464a-a777-d86356c53f00.name: Chainsaw Maintenance & Crosscutting - Training

badge_template_activities.title: To understand the regulations & safety requirements related to the use of chainsaws and industry good practice.
To understand how to and to be able to prepare and maintain the chainsaw and cutting system for use.
To be able to carry out operational chainsaw checks
To crosscut timber to specified standards of accuracy using safe efficient techniques.
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading
To remove branches from felled trees, using a chainsaw (sned), to specified standards of safety & quality.
To be able to work safely.

3ab1f40a-672e-4965-a44f-aff1578637ce.description: This course is for operators who are able to use a chainsaw for crosscutting, but are now required to progress on to felling and processing trees of a small diameter (up to 380mm).
3ab1f40a-672e-4965-a44f-aff1578637ce.name: Felling & Processing Small Trees up to 380mm - Training

badge_template_activities.title: To understand the regulations & safety requirements related to the use of chainsaws and industry good practice.
To fell, safely and accurately, trees up to guide bar length in diameter (380mm).
To remove branches from felled trees, using a chainsaw (sned), to specified standards of safety & quality.
To use appropriate aid tools & techniques for take down of lodged trees and for directional felling.
To crosscut timber to specified standards of accuracy using safe efficient techniques.
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading
To be able to work safely.

4d25061a-f7bd-48fe-8e9d-de455f95e2ec.description: This course is for anyone required to use a manually fed woodchipper as part of their work or for personal use. This would include novices and experienced operators who require their skills up-dating.
4d25061a-f7bd-48fe-8e9d-de455f95e2ec.name: Manually Fed Woodchippers - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand the relevant legislation and safety guidelines for using a woodchipper.
Select the appropriate PPE and state its maintenance requirements.
Carry out operator checks and routine operator maintenance, including the cutting mechanism & safety features of a woodchipper.
Produce a site specific risk assessment for wood chipping operations.
Position machine for operation, start the machine, carry out safety checks and stop machine.
Prepare a work area and a range of materials for chipping and identify hazardous materials to avoid.
Use safe and effective methods to chip woody brash and both short and long sections of timber.
Understand the procedure for removing blockages.
Know the safety and environmental factors associated with the disposal of woodchips and a range of end uses for woodchips.
Clean & tidy site to specification and prepare machine for transport and storage.

a89dd1c8-800a-40d3-a88b-21d8114a6be7.description: This course is for anyone required to use a brushcutter trimmer or strimmer as part of their work or for personal use. This would include novices and experienced operators who require their skills up-dating.
a89dd1c8-800a-40d3-a88b-21d8114a6be7.name: Brushcutter Trimmer - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Prepares for the machine for safe and effective use.
Maintains the machine, cutting head and the blade to manufacturers’ guidelines.
Prepares the machine and sets harness ready for work.
Uses the machine for cutting vegetation to prescribed standards using both trimmer and brushcutter heads
Cleans and prepares machine for transport and storage.

2c5b6fe0-19cf-4b02-893b-99654fa1318c.description: This Digital Credential shows that this participant undertook 2 days classroom teaching and observation-based training in the use of mobile cranes in arboriculture. The aim of this course is to enable participants to have an introduction to the various roles and tasks to be able to understand and subsequently undertake elements of crane assisted aerial tree work. This course has been developed by Arborcraft and mwmac Ltd, with funding support from Focus on Forestry First Ltd.
2c5b6fe0-19cf-4b02-893b-99654fa1318c.name: Introduction to Use of Mobile Cranes in Arboriculture

badge_template_activities.title: The current legislation and industry guidance related to crane assisted tree work.
Interpretation of the lift plan and production of ‘RAMS’ for the arboricultural aspects of the operation.
Organisation of the site in accordance with the ‘RAMS’ and lift plan.
Communication with the crane operator / lift supervisor effectively using recognised and agreed signals.
The arboricultural ground-based roles and processing of lowered sections.
Estimation of the weight and centre of gravity of sections.
Safely attaching climbing equipment to the hook block and accessing the crown.
Appropriate selection and attachment of slings / lifting accessories.
Methods of severing tree sections using appropriate cutting techniques.

3b9b1b36-c974-4853-81d6-82376ea881c8.description: This is a combined course, covering both the theory and the practical application, using handheld applicators. This course is aimed at anyone using professional pesticide products in industries like agriculture, horticulture, and forestry. If your job involves applying pesticides in a commercial role then you are legally required by the Plant Protection Products (Sustainable Use) Regulations (2012) to take this qualification. This course includes the spraying near water (AW) as standard.
3b9b1b36-c974-4853-81d6-82376ea881c8.name: Principles & Application of Pesticides using Pedestrian Handheld Applicators - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand operators’ responsibilities under current legislation controlling use of pesticides.
Read & Interpret a product label and literature
Understand PPE required, its suitability & personal hygiene
Understand the operator’s responsibilities with regard to pesticide container storage & disposal
Be aware of personal contamination procedures
Be aware of accurate record keeping & how to keep accurate application records
Be aware of environmental and wildlife factors when using a pesticide
Have knowledge to prepare site for applying pesticides
Understand the basic components of a knapsack sprayer and select appropriate nozzle
Calibrate applicator and carry out procedures for measuring, measuring, mixing & filling applicator.
Know how to maintain, clean and store applicators

5b00172a-dbe3-4208-85b7-19cd956b6ab8.description: This course is for those who need to develop their knowledge of health and safety legislation for Pesticides and Pesticides application; but not necessarily directly apply pesticides themselves.
5b00172a-dbe3-4208-85b7-19cd956b6ab8.name: Principles of Safe Handling and Application of Pesticides (theory) - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand operators’ responsibilities under current legislation controlling use of pesticides.
Read & Interpret a product label and literature
Understand PPE required, its suitability & personal hygiene
Understand the operator’s responsibilities with regard to pesticide container storage & disposal
Be aware of personal contamination procedures
Be aware of accurate record keeping & how to keep accurate application records
Be aware of environmental and wildlife factors when using a pesticide
Have knowledge to prepare site for applying pesticides

1ead3ded-943c-4622-9bdc-681643ad4db8.description: This course is for experienced chainsaw operators who are required to fell and process trees of a diameter over 380mm but under 760mm.
1ead3ded-943c-4622-9bdc-681643ad4db8.name: Felling & Processing Medium Trees over 380mm and up to 760mm - Training

badge_template_activities.title: To understand the regulations, legislation & safety requirements related to the use of chainsaws and industry good practice.
To understand and practice Health & Safety, Risk Assessment, Tree Felling Legislation and Environmental Protection
To fell, safely and accurately, trees over 380mm diameter; upright, backward and forward weighted trees.
Snedding or de-limbing techniques for larger trees, to specified standard of safety and quality.
To use appropriate aid tools & techniques for take down of hung-up trees; what not to do and the use of winches.
To crosscut stems over guidebar diameter by use of reducing cus or by cutting from both sides, to specified standards of accuracy using safe efficient techniques.
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading.
To be able to work safely.

bc5ada09-69c2-4cf9-993d-8b1619b0551f.description: Tree climbing is an essential part of an Arborist’s work, however, working at height can be dangerous. This course provides attendees with the skills and knowledge to effectively and safely climb trees in preparation for arb works or as part of tree or canopy inspection works. Falls from height are one of the biggest causes of deaths and major injuries in the workplace; this course includes, as standard, effective aerial rescue techniques.
bc5ada09-69c2-4cf9-993d-8b1619b0551f.name: Tree Climbing & Aerial Rescue - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understands legislation relevant to tree climbing. (Safety legislation, tree + wildlife protection)
Identifies basic equipment required for tree climbing, including conformity and inspection requirements with reference to the LOLER regulations.
Understands the principles of work positioning and work positioning systems. (climber attached to tree at all times, maximum allowable slack and fall)
Identifies a range of equipment to facilitate initial access into the tree crown, Strengths and weaknesses. (e.g. ladder, throwline, rods)
Tie a range of knots relevant to tree climbing operations. (attachment knots, friction hitches, stopper knots)
Inspects tree to establish whether it is safe to climb.
Establish anchor points and perform change overs safely.
Ascend the tree to an appropriate final anchor point using techniques conforming to work positioning principles.
Carry out branch walks to the outer portions of the tree crown.
Use handsaw to remove lightweight branches, including correct pruning techniques.
Carry out aerial rescues of casualties using a variety of techniques and from different situations.
Carry out pole rescue

2805fbb9-db46-4627-8def-d9a511d6ee5b.description: This course is for those who are already qualified arborists who would like to enhance their skills further in arboriculture. Often when carrying out works on trees, standard free-fall techniques are not suitable, this is where aerial rigging comes in. This specialist course will provide you with the knowledge, skills and understanding to carry out aerial tree rigging and safe dismantling techniques.
2805fbb9-db46-4627-8def-d9a511d6ee5b.name: Aerial Rigging - Training

badge_template_activities.title: To be able to assess requirements and limitations for tree rigging operations.
To be able to calculate loads
To be able to select rigging equipment appropriate for the task and loads.
To be able to remove branches with the assistance of various lowering methods.
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading.
To be able to work safely.

b8f13159-0f2b-42ff-8713-a63ac177a701.description: This course is for chainsaw operators who require the assistance of winch systems to safely and effectively fell trees.
b8f13159-0f2b-42ff-8713-a63ac177a701.name: Assisted Felling - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand the conditions necessary for the safe & effective use of the winch or rope, including legislative requirements and controls to prevent environmental damage.
Understand the differences between winch assisted and conventional tree felling and understand situations that can occur in felling trees using winch or rope assistance
Understand the condition, controls & safety features of the pulling equipment component parts.
Understand the ancillary chokering & anchoring equipment & identify worn or damaged components and describe compatibility of components in the system.

Understand the preparation of the pulling system to assist in tree felling operation, including correct positioning and configuration of chokers/ slings and any intermediate pulleys and correct choice of anchor point.
A ‘’failsafe’’ required in the winching system such as the use of wedges by chainsaw operator to support to support tree during felling operation.
Understand setting up snatch block/pulley for offset pulling &describe and the hazards involved including the risk zones and increased loads imposed on the intermediate anchor point.
Agree a signalling system between winch operator and chainsaw operator and tension system as appropriate
Winch assisted tree felling operation, safe & effective, under control of chainsaw operator
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading.
To be able to work safely.

f4bec2d9-4672-477d-ae2a-5609f892de63.description: This course is for supervisors and managers who are required to plan or prepare for emergency tree work operations (i.e. trees falling during a storm) for a gang or group of chainsaw operators. This course would also be beneficial for landowners who own woodlands and wooded areas (such as trees in hedgerows or on roadsides).
f4bec2d9-4672-477d-ae2a-5609f892de63.name: Emergency Tree Works Planning - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand relevant health and safety legislation and industry good practice in relation to Emergency Tree Work Operations
Understand how to plan, agree and carry out Emergency Tree Work operations
Be able to promote health and safety and industry good practice
Be able to carry out emergency treework operations

a1ad140c-702e-4cae-8526-8ad2e5996daf.description: This advanced course is for experienced chainsaw operators who are required to fell and process trees of a large diameter (over 760mm)
a1ad140c-702e-4cae-8526-8ad2e5996daf.name: Felling & Processing Large Trees over 760mm - Training

badge_template_activities.title: To understand the regulations, legislation & safety requirements related to the use of chainsaws and industry good practice.
To be able to fell large trees using a chainsaw
To remove branches, including crown breakdown, to specified standards of safety & quality.
To crosscut timber to specified standards of accuracy using safe efficient techniques.
To present produce as specified for subsequent extraction or loading
To be able to work safely.

ab59e0e7-0a37-44bd-9cfc-c48afafae3cd.description: This is course for those who work with Forest Machinery, specifically for Tractor Base, Forwarder Trailer and Winch Skidder.
ab59e0e7-0a37-44bd-9cfc-c48afafae3cd.name: FMO Tractor (Rigid Base), Forwarder & Winch Skidder - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Identify and comply with manufacturer’s instructions for machinery in accordance with the operators’ manual,and other information sources, and applicable legislation.
To understand HSE requirements including PUWER and LOLER.
Can carry out and complete a Risk Assessment for tasks involving rigid base and forwarding trailer
Identify the basic construction and components of the base unit, and forwarding trailer, and skidder winchincluding identifying the purpose and use of all controls and gauges.
Carry out pre start checks, and daily maintenance checks.
Know how to and be able to prepare and drive the machine
Know how to and be able to operate a forwarder crane
Know relevant health & safety legislation and industry good practice
Complete job to a given specification, following environmental good practice
Be able to work safely

ffb15c0a-9f3e-42ec-b8f0-d80dfad77cc1.description: This training course is for experienced chainsaw operators who are required to tackle multiple windblown trees which may be interwoven, snapped and/or part blown (such as a clear-fell/windblown site). This course utilises the assistance of winches for the restraint of the tree.
ffb15c0a-9f3e-42ec-b8f0-d80dfad77cc1.name: Dealing with Interwoven & Part Blown Trees - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Understand background, Risk Assessment, HSE Guidance and Environmental Protection
Sever blown stems under and over guidebar diameter
Restraint of rootplates or stems with side tension (inc. SWL’s, PUWER & LOLER)
Deal with half blown trees
Deal with snapped trees and felling standing stems

1797cebf-b129-4f34-9323-68d4f81c628d.description: This 1 day Emergency First Aid at Work (EFAW) course enables a first-aider to give emergency first aid to someone who is injured or becomes ill while at work. The + Forestry (or +F) indicates that this course has been designed to include additional objectives/training points specifically for the Forestry or Arboricultural Sectors. This digital credential will expire 3 years from date of training, as per HSE guidelines.
1797cebf-b129-4f34-9323-68d4f81c628d.name: Emergency First Aid at Work + Forestry

badge_template_activities.title: Understand the role of the first aider, including reference to: the importance of preventing cross infection | the need for recording incidents and actions | use of available equipment
Assess the situation and circumstances to act safely, promptly and effectively in an emergency
Administer first aid to a casualty who is unconscious (including seizure)
Administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation
Administer first aid to a casualty who is choking
Administer first aid to a casualty who is wounded and bleeding
Administer first aid to a casualty who is suffering from shock
Provide appropriate first aid for minor injuries (including small cuts, grazes and bruises, minor burns and scalds, small splinters).

+ Forestry Modules: Getting help in remote locations | Catastrophic bleeding | Suspension Trauma | Crush Injury | High Pressure Hose injury | Lyme Disease | Emergency Blood-clotting agents | Amputation

10cc0f81-83e9-44c2-9eea-bfff297f8b6e.description: This course is for qualified operators who wish to refresh their training regarding their knowledge of health and safety legislation for Pesticides and Pesticides application. Refresher Training is recommended every 3 to 5 years.
10cc0f81-83e9-44c2-9eea-bfff297f8b6e.name: Principles of Safe Handling and Application of Pesticides (theory) - Refresher

badge_template_activities.title: Understand operators’ responsibilities under current legislation controlling use of pesticides.
Read & Interpret a product label and literature
Understand PPE required, its suitability & personal hygiene
Understand the operator’s responsibilities with regard to pesticide container storage & disposal
Be aware of personal contamination procedures
Be aware of accurate record keeping & how to keep accurate application records
Be aware of environmental and wildlife factors when using a pesticide
Have knowledge to prepare site for applying pesticides

d3425dd6-92a5-4745-bef1-db3e8df93106.description: This course is intended for those who are already experienced in climbing trees and using work positioning systems. This course is for those wishing to progress in the arboricultural sector, to using a chainsaw from a rope and harness, and learn safe and effective free-fall techniques.
d3425dd6-92a5-4745-bef1-db3e8df93106.name: Use of a Chainsaw from a Rope & Harness - Training

badge_template_activities.title: Are aware of the legislation and safety guidelines pertaining to tree climbing and use of chainsaw from a rope and harness.
Are aware of the safety considerations to be observed in organising the work site. Is aware of the range of PPE appropriate to the Work Positioning System.
Is able to use appropriate techniques for movement within the crown and to establish secure and comfortable work positions.
Understands the importance of, and is able to apply, correct final pruning positions, the 1-2-3 method of branch removal and the appropriate use of step and sink cuts.
Is able to use top-handled and rear handled chainsaws in a safe and efficient manner to remove light and medium-weight branches.
Recognises and is able to fulfil the duties and responsibilities of a competent grounds man.
